required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Omega-3 Fatty Acids on Risk Factors for Breast Cancer in Pre-menopausal Women
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Omega-3 Fatty Acids on Risk Factors for Breast Cancer in Pre-menopausal Women

brief_summary.textblock: Healthy premenopausal women were enrolled in a diet intervention study that examined the effect of a combination EPA/DHA supplement on risk factors associated with breast cancer. In a randomized cross-over design, women consumed their habitual diet with a supplement for three menstrual cycles, had three cycles of wash-out and then consumed a low-fat diet with the same supplement. Blood, urine and nipple aspirate fluid were collected periodically over the 10 month protocol and analyzed for biomarkers associated with supplementation and future risk of breast cancer.

detailed_description.textblock: Non-pregnant, non-lactating women aged 18+ were recruited by way of posters, to take part in a dietary intervention study that was examining the effects of dietary fat level and fat type on risk factors associated with breast cancer. Women who were normally menstruating, consumed either their habitual diet or a low-fat diet for three menstrual cycles, along with a supplement containing 1.2 g DHA+EPA /day. This was followed by a 3-menstrual cycle washout, where the habitual diet was consumed without a supplement. Subsequently the participants consumed the other diet (either low-fat or habitual) for a further 3 menstrual cycles with the 1.2 g DHA/EPA supplement. Blood, urine and nipple aspirate fluid were collected at the beginning and end of each intervention period and analyzed for a variety of biomarkers. Diet records were collected continuously over the entire study period and periodic 7-day records examined for collection of detailed nutrition information. Anthropometry was completed at each study visit, and nutritional counselling provided throughout.

primary_outcome.measure: omega-3 fatty acid incorporation into red blood cells
primary_outcome.description: replacement of omega-6 long chain fatty acids with DHA and EPA in red blood cell membranes

primary_outcome.measure: omega-3 fatty acid incorporation in cell material from nipple aspirate fluid
primary_outcome.description: replacement of omega-6 fatty acids with omega-3 fatty acids in the cells sloughed into the ductal fluid and collected. Total fatty acids from PL fraction of NAF.

secondary_outcome.measure: changes in estrogen in blood and nipple aspirate fluid
secondary_outcome.description: modification of estrogen production following omega-3 fatty acid consumption

secondary_outcome.measure: changes in oxidative estrogen metabolites in urine
secondary_outcome.description: lower concentrations of oxidized estrogen metabolites expected with omega-3 fatty acid supplementation.
lower body weight expected with implementation of the low-fat diet

arm_group.description: habitual diet with 1.2 g EPA+DHA in capsule form/day.
Reduce dietary fat to less than 20% energy, add 1.2 g EPA+DHA in capsule form/day.

intervention.description: SEE YOURSELF WELLTM OMEGA-3 Dietary Supplement: See Yourself Well Inc., Leamington, Ontario) containinged 200 mg of EPA and 100 mg of DHA for a total of 1.2 g n-3/day.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria: menstruating, pre-menopausal -
Exclusion Criteria: pregnant, lactating, post-menopausal, smoking, on birth control pills

overall_official.affiliation: Research Ethics Officer, University of Guelph
